title: Flight to Tokyo
helpfulInfo: Use the Narita Express (covered by the JR Pass) to reach Shinjuku in about 75 min; after check-in, stretch your legs in nearby Omoide Yokocho and sample late-night yakitori.

title: Tokyo
highlights: Tokyo's oldest Buddhist temple Senso-ji, founded in the 7th century, with its Kaminarimon gate and giant red lantern; panoramic city views from Tokyo Skytree (634 m, the world’s tallest tower); Nakamise shopping street leading to Senso-ji, lined with stalls selling traditional snacks and souvenirs.
helpfulInfo: Senso-ji’s grounds never close, but the main hall is open roughly 6 AM–5 PM. Visit early or after dark to enjoy illuminated lanterns without crowds. Tokyo Skytree runs 10 AM–9 PM (last entry 8 PM); book timed tickets online to skip queues. Dining is plentiful in the Solamachi mall below.

title: Tokyo → Hakone
highlights: Meiji Jingu Shrine set in a 70-hectare forest; Harajuku’s Takeshita Street packed with youth fashion and colorful crepes; Shibuya Crossing—the world’s busiest pedestrian scramble—flanked by neon billboards and the Hachikō statue.
helpfulInfo: Meiji Jingu opens sunrise–sunset and is free; purify at the temizuya, then bow-clap-bow when praying. Takeshita Street shops start ~11 AM; weekdays are quieter. View Shibuya Crossing from the Magnet rooftop or Shibuya Sky deck before catching the Odakyu Romancecar to Hakone-Yumoto (seat surcharge for JR Pass holders).

title: Hakone
highlights: Hakone onsen region famed for Mount Fuji views; Owakudani volcanic valley with black sulfur-boiled eggs; Lake Ashi pirate-ship cruise offering postcard vistas; numerous ryokan bathhouses for traditional hot-spring soaking.
helpfulInfo: Buy a Hakone Free Pass for unlimited rides on trains, buses, boats and ropeway. Follow onsen etiquette—wash thoroughly before soaking and keep towels out of the water. Aim for an early cruise or ropeway trip for your best chance at a clear Fuji view; the Hakone Open-Air Museum is an excellent rainy-day fallback.

title: Hakone → Kyoto
highlights: Arashiyama Bamboo Grove; Tenryu-ji Temple’s UNESCO Zen garden; Kinkaku-ji (Golden Pavilion) shimmering across its mirror pond.
helpfulInfo: Arrive in Arashiyama at sunrise for an uncrowded bamboo stroll; Tenryu-ji garden opens 8 :30 AM (¥500). Reach Kinkaku-ji by mid-afternoon (9 AM–5 PM, ¥400) and photograph the pavilion from the first viewpoint before the path becomes one-way.

title: Kyoto
highlights: Fushimi Inari Taisha’s endless vermilion torii tunnels; Gion district’s lantern-lit machiya and glimpses of geiko; Yasaka Shrine, lively with illuminated lanterns each evening.
helpfulInfo: Visit Fushimi Inari at dawn to enjoy quiet trails—no fee and open 24 h. Spend late afternoon wandering Hanamikoji in Gion; photography is banned on some private alleys—respect signs. Yasaka Shrine (free) is atmospheric after sunset; consider a short cultural show at nearby Gion Corner.

title: Kyoto
highlights: Philosopher’s Path (Tetsugaku-no-michi) lined with cherry trees; Ginkaku-ji (Silver Pavilion) and its raked sand garden; Nanzen-ji temple area with brick aqueduct and mossy sub-gardens.
helpfulInfo: Enter Ginkaku-ji at the 8 :30 AM opening (¥500) for tranquil views; stroll the 2 km Philosopher’s Path in 30–40 min, popping into Honen-in en route. Nanzen-ji’s free grounds never close, but paid areas shut 4 :30 PM (¥600). Keage subway whisks you back downtown in 10 min.

title: Kyoto
highlights: Nijo-jo Castle, the Tokugawa shogun’s Kyoto residence famed for ‘nightingale floors’; Nishiki Market, a 400-year-old food arcade dubbed “Kyoto’s Kitchen”; Pontocho alley, a narrow lane beside the Kamo River packed with lantern-lit eateries and hidden bars.
helpfulInfo: Nijo-jo opens 8 :45 AM (last entry 4 PM, ¥1 300); shoes off inside the palace. Nishiki Market bustles 10 AM–6 PM—sample pickles, yuba and mochi as you go. At dusk, cross Shijo Bridge into Pontocho; photograph lanterns but don’t block doorways, and expect a cover charge at many kaiseki restaurants.

title: Kyoto → Osaka
helpfulInfo: Osaka Castle's museum reopened 2025—buy timed ticket online; sample takoyaki at Dotonbori (15 min subway).

title: Osaka
helpfulInfo: Ride the Hankai tram to Sumiyoshi Taisha (¥230); finish with sunset views from Abeno Harukas observatory (open until 22:00).

title: Osaka → Kanazawa
helpfulInfo: Kenroku-en is free before 07:00; combine with Kanazawa Castle via the Ishikawa Gate; buy a Loop-Bus day pass (¥600).

title: Kanazawa
helpfulInfo: In Nagamachi samurai district visit Nomura-ke with English audio; try gold-leaf ice cream in Higashi-Chaya.

title: Kanazawa → Tokyo
helpfulInfo: Reserve a window seat on the Kagayaki Shinkansen for Sea-of-Japan views the first 30 min; send bags to airport hotel.

title: Tokyo
highlights: Meiji-Schrein – https://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3002.html ; Harajuku – https://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3006.html ; Shibuya – https://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3007.html
helpfulInfo: Meiji Shrine opens at dawn; after Harajuku crepes, pre-book Shibuya Sky sunset slot online.

title: Tokyo → Kanagawa
helpfulInfo: Pay ¥50 to walk inside Kamakura's Great Buddha; ride Yokohama's Cosmo Clock 17 after dark for skyline photos.

title: Yokohama
helpfulInfo: Book a private tea room in Sankeien Garden (¥3 000/hr) and a sunset cruise from Osanbashi pier (1 h).

title: Yokohama → Tokyo
helpfulInfo: Use the Metro 24-h ticket (¥600) for unlimited rides; consider teamLab Borderless in Azabudai Hills (opened 2024).

title: Flight to Hawaii
helpfulInfo: Check-in opens three hours before departure; airport Muji is perfect for last-minute gifts.
